There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist towns. We don't have large city malls, Walmart, Target, or even Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the world's most beautiful places, surrounded by water. My "town" is nestled between the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find beaches to dip your toes in everywhere you turn.

My neighborhood embodies small-town charm. The houses aren't cramped together or built from the same cookie-cutter design. They're older homes, some renovated and updated, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many feature classic aluminum siding. The houses in our area display every color imaginable, and most properties have yards where you'll find trampolines and playground equipment. Some residents maintain gardens or have fenced areas for their pets.

These homes represent quintessential Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already done so. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, ride bikes, or rollerblade. Neighbors know each other well enough to spot who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see people grilling outdoors and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away exchanging friendly smiles.

The properties are well-maintained, with no leftover fall leaves, neatly mowed lawns, and properly trimmed bushes and plants. While it's not the kind of neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that immediately strikes you as an ideal place to raise a family. It's peaceful, quiet, and secure - representing what many people seek: a safe haven at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, and the city recycling center, which serves the entire community. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of announcers calling games. Our small town airport adds to the ambiance with the occasional sound of small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and ambitious walkers can even reach downtown. My children can bicycle to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is an wonderful place to call home.

I live in what could be described as a typical suburban development. Our neighborhood is notably governed by a homeowners' association (HOA). Upon arrival, you'll notice rows of meticulously maintained single-family homes - a direct result of HOA oversight. The front yards follow a consistent pattern: small manicured lawns, decorative stone features, compact driveways, and occasional small trees. Every home comes with a two-car garage.

The neighborhood infrastructure is impressive, with freshly maintained concrete roads showing no signs of deterioration despite serving numerous families. While most residences are single-story, you'll occasionally find two-story homes. Rather than individual mailboxes at each house, we have a centralized mail station system similar to apartment complexes, with secured individual boxes and package lockers - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our location sits at the city's periphery, creating an interesting blend of suburban and rural characteristics. This provides ample space for numerous amenities, including multiple gated community pools accessible to all residents, and extensive walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood itself is large enough to serve as an exercise circuit, eliminating the need for separate park visits.

The community demographic primarily consists of retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a secure environment where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern conveniences, including a modest but functional mall. Most destinations require about a 15-minute drive, but once there, you'll find plenty of retail options ranging from upscale organic grocery stores to budget-friendly discount outlets.

In essence, our neighborhood embodies typical suburban living with excellent maintenance and security. While shopping isn't immediately accessible, a short drive connects you to any major retail chain you might need, and our community amenities like pools and walking trails add significant value to the living experience.

I first learned about where I live through a podcast about missing persons cases. It was surprising, considering most apartments in the area cost over a thousand dollars monthly. Neither I nor my friends had heard about that story before. Perhaps it's the daily struggle that affects us all. I know several friends who cry themselves to sleep, wrestling with life's expenses, though we've become experts at living frugally. You learn to appreciate the musty charm of flea market finds and second-hand clothes. Your sense of smell seems to dull with age - maybe from smoking, or maybe you just get used to how things are. But the flea market's distinct atmosphere is always present. Adulthood smells like dusty magazines piled on an unused piano, a scent that seeps into leather and persists even after washing.

In this neighborhood, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charitable thrift shops, a library, a bookstore specializing in rare volumes, and an antique shop. While downtown bustles with cars and pedestrians every morning, the thrift stores remain oddly peaceful. No matter how busy the streets get, these spaces stay quiet - perfect for whiling away an afternoon. Each year brings more people and vehicles as the city develops, particularly as home to one of the largest e-commerce and delivery companies. The growing pains remind me of New York - everyone focused on their own path, asking little of others. You can maintain your privacy and independence without interference. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a cultural norm, people here respect personal boundaries.

Living here has its charm. Between my pianist neighbor and two aspiring singers upstairs, there's never a dull moment. We're less a building of strangers and more an actual community. We support each other through celebrations and sorrows, sharing resources and assistance when needed. I feel fortunate to have landed here. My neighbors are wonderful people who treat me well, and I reciprocate by being considerate and sharing food. We help with small tasks like delivering mail, and our interactions are genuinely pleasant. Despite living in what could be seen as an impersonal urban sprawl, it's the people around me who make this place feel like home and remind me that I made the right choice after all.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburban boundaries of a major city. I live in the eastern section, which is considered the most economically challenged part of town. While property values here are modest, with most residences either rented or owned by lower-income families, the area maintains its own charm. The neighbors are generally warm and welcoming, often exchanging friendly greetings during walks.

Though crime rates are slightly elevated compared to other areas of town, they remain relatively low overall. In the past decade, there have been several serious incidents within blocks of my home, including some shootings and one homicide. Tragically, our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting incident near a local bar last year. Our family has been fortunate to experience only minor issues, such as occasional items disappearing from our porch when left outside.

Like many American communities, our town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, the community has responded with various support systems, including rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for affected families.

Despite these challenges, our town has numerous positive aspects. The local elementary school, where my son attends, is exceptional, with dedicated staff at all levels. My son, who has special needs, thrives in the school's inclusive environment and has been free from bullying. The school's parent-teacher organization is very active, organizing various events throughout the year. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, the school provides free meals to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry and no family feels stigmatized.

The city administration has made considerable improvements to the town's infrastructure and appearance, though these enhancements have primarily focused on the central and western areas, where most commerce occurs. The eastern section, where I live, often receives less attention, which frustrates local residents.

Nevertheless, I find this town a satisfying place to call home. The community is friendly, the educational system is strong, and there are sufficient shopping options to meet our needs. While our house may not have high market value, it provides a comfortable living space. After sixteen years here, my family can't imagine settling anywhere else.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural richness, perched atop a hill and embraced by historically significant buildings. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, and just down the slope, there's this charming arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. During June and July weekends especially, you'll often find people queuing to enter.

A few blocks uphill lies the city park, surprisingly spacious for its urban location. Concrete walls with broad steps surround it. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalks and steps. While snow is rare, the heavy winter rains make staying warm a challenge. By clustering their tents in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and maintain convenient access to the area's only family center where they can maintain personal hygiene.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historic charm - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's spirit that truly moves me. Hilltop, once infamous along the West Coast for gang activity, still echoes with stories from three decades past about federal and DEA interventions. These narratives live on, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself.

Despite its reputation as one of the city's tougher areas, residents take pride in maintaining their neighborhood. There's an old warning about white people avoiding the Hill after dark, but I see this as a remnant of past times, tainted by social prejudice. Whether it's because my appearance isn't typically "white," or because Hilltop has accepted me as one of its own, I've found a community that understands the ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions - even in a supposedly diverse urban utopia.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home. I feel energized walking its nighttime streets, encountering people more likely to offer me protection than harm. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours to shelter someone from rain, where strangers offer unexpected kindness - like the time someone noticed me huddled against a storefront on a gloomy night, offered me money, and reminded me of my worth and beauty.

I moved to this neighborhood just before starting eighth grade. Initially, making friends was challenging, but I eventually became close with someone living two houses down and another person on my street. Although they've since moved away, the memories remain vivid. Most of the original residents from when I first moved here still live in the area. My neighborhood is typical of American suburbs, featuring numerous two-story homes. During warm weather, especially on weekends, you can hear children playing outside. The area remains peaceful most days, and I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors. People here respect your privacy but are willing to help when needed. I've never had packages stolen from my porch, which speaks to the trustworthiness of my neighbors.

There's a park just a couple of minutes from my house that holds many memories for me. I've played various sports there with neighborhood friends, including basketball, football, and baseball. While I did have one unfortunate incident where I got elbowed in the nose during football, the positive memories far outweigh the negative ones. These days, I mainly visit the park with my cousin's children, who get excited about the playground equipment like swings and slides. The park now fills me with nostalgia for many different reasons.

Our neighborhood is culturally diverse, which is reflected in the local dining options. Within a mile radius, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, though many people now prefer using delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food establishments are popular here, as they are in most suburban areas, and there are numerous pizza places as well.

The area offers all necessary amenities, including multiple dry cleaners, both Walgreens and CVS pharmacies, and a Midwest-favorite Jewel-Osco grocery store. The cultural diversity extends to retail, with specialty stores like an Indian grocery store for those interested in authentic Indian ingredients or prepared foods.

Overall, I truly appreciate my neighborhood, especially when I read about others' negative experiences with their neighbors on social media and in the news. It makes me particularly grateful for my community.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is one of the reasons I enjoy living there. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered around. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier, but the service and drinks are still decent. The community is diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, due to the affordable housing options. There's a lively presence of children because of a nearby elementary school within walking distance.

While I don't know my neighbors personally (and prefer it that way), there's an amusing situation where management installed an air freshener outside one apartment due to frequent cannabis use - something my boyfriend and I find rather comical and almost passive-aggressive. The surrounding buildings are generally older, though some have updated interiors. Further down the street, there are new apartment complexes, but I'm wary of their quality - they seem hastily constructed yet charge premium rates, taking advantage of their proximity to campus.

There's an incredibly budget-friendly restaurant nearby that serves microwave-heated food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. The area recently benefited from city funding that improved the road infrastructure, adding wide sidewalks and landscaping with grass medians, enhancing the overall appearance. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, though some have been removed, leaving stumps. We have significantly more tree coverage than other parts of the neighborhood.

The contrast between streets is notable - I live on 42nd Street, while 43rd Street behind us is noticeably more run-down, with deteriorating sidewalks and shabby buildings partially concealed by dense tree coverage. While there have been crime issues in certain complexes, particularly on 43rd Street and across from my building, I generally feel satisfied with my living situation. The rent is affordable, amenities are convenient, and I especially appreciate being able to walk to the university and having easy access to public transportation for reaching stores and downtown.

I live in a unique neighborhood of duplexes arranged along a cul-de-sac. The buildings are strategically placed to resemble single-family homes, all featuring yellow exteriors with white porches and green metal roofs. Most residents here have formed friendly bonds with one another. We often gather spontaneously at the end of driveways in the evening, engaging in casual conversation while neighborhood children play with their toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. In this modern world dominated by technology, our community offers a refreshing glimpse into a simpler time.

We're blessed with scenic surroundings - fields and trees beneath blue skies dotted with fluffy white clouds. The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and recently, we experienced our first real tornado siren alert. I found myself seeking shelter in my bathtub, clutching my small dog, purse, and some pillows. My larger dog, anxious about the unusual situation, refused to leave the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of large hailstones falling. After the storm, the road literally steamed as the temperature dropped dramatically from 92 to 75 degrees within minutes. The hot pavement instantly melted the hail. As the skies cleared, a magical moment occurred - the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture this spectacular sight on camera to share with friends and family on Facebook.

The neighborhood remained quiet for about an hour until residents who had sought shelter elsewhere returned home. Soon, life returned to normal, with mothers and children outdoors while dinner prepared. As someone who recently relocated from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I find this friendly southern community delightful, complete with its charming accents. While all duplexes appear identical from the outside, each two-bedroom, two-bathroom unit varies inside, with some surprisingly compact layouts.

I particularly enjoy walking along the large field behind my home to the nearby pond (though it's not for swimming). The area teems with wildlife - deer frequent the area, and mornings are marked by the deep croaking of bullfrogs. Located just forty minutes from Charlotte, this location offers the perfect blend of rural charm and urban accessibility. Each day begins with roosters crowing from neighboring farms, creating the atmosphere of a small village community. We even have a local donkey whose evening braying serves as a familiar reminder of our rural setting. I consider myself fortunate to have discovered this wonderful neighborhood.

Having spent about a decade here, I feel qualified to share my experience. When I first moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was heartbroken. I won't deny shedding tears over leaving loved ones behind, but my parents made this choice for better opportunities for me and my sister - better housing, superior schools, and what people would call a "nicer area."

Over time, I adapted and made both friends and rivals at school. While I didn't get to know many neighbors, Mr. Glen, his family, and Dennis, who lived next door, became almost like family to us. I have fond memories of attending Mr. Glen's second wedding with my family. It was a joyous celebration where I even caught the garter, though the bouquet eluded me! I had a wonderful time dancing with Marsharii, one of his daughters, whom I haven't seen since. I hope she's thriving wherever she is now.

The neighborhood is quite intricate, like a maze, but GPS helps me explore it better now. I've ventured out mainly with my friends Kason and Curtis, spending countless hours playing video games and living life to the fullest. I find peace in visiting the local park, where nature calms my spirit. I practice balance with sticks from Home Depot and sometimes bring my wooden bokken sword - just doing what brings me joy.

There's also a basketball and tennis court nearby. While I haven't played either sport recently, it's nice knowing they're available. Tennis holds special memories - my dad and Mr. Graves coached me and my best friend, pushing us hard but always keeping it fun.

This neighborhood has given me countless memorable moments, and I believe the best experiences are still ahead!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. While it may not particularly stand out among other South Carolina towns, it plays a significant role in agriculture. Johnston proudly calls itself the Peach Capital of the World, as displayed on its welcome sign. The landscape is dominated by peach orchards and cattle farms. Outside the town center, homes are generously spaced apart, typically two stories high with either metal roofs to combat the intense summer heat or traditional gray shingles. Most houses are set back from the road, leaving front areas for farming or grazing.

The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all local businesses are concentrated. For dining options, there are three choices: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a local burger establishment. A pizza place once existed but has since closed. The town has Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. There's also IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), the town's only, albeit expensive, grocery store. Most residents prefer to do their main shopping at the Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville, using IGA only for quick purchases.

Dollar General is the town's most popular store, offering various everyday items and staying busy throughout its operating hours. Possibilities Furniture & More, a long-standing establishment run by a well-respected community member, offers furniture delivery service. Adjacent to it is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, providing pet care services including grooming, boarding, and daycare.

The town has both a medical clinic and veterinary practice located outside the center, small but well-equipped to serve local needs. Johnston Elementary School serves younger students, while middle and high school students must attend school in the neighboring town. While the town currently lacks parks, there are plans to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance community life and attract visitors.

Though Johnston lacks entertainment venues like movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, or diverse dining options, it maintains its charm as a small town - one so modest you might miss it in the blink of an eye!

I reside in a typical suburban area of a small Tennessee town in the South. Our street connects two state highways, which brings more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise, it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of my neighbors. People generally keep themselves busy with yard maintenance and daily routines. During winter, children enjoy sledding down the hill on our side street. Our house sits at the corner of the street, giving us a clear view of all the comings and goings, and we're familiar with the vehicles our neighbors drive. We tend to notice when unfamiliar cars appear.

Some neighbors exercise by walking or take their dogs out for strolls. Children ride their bikes and engage in typical neighborhood activities. Since we work from home, our family of four - my wife, our two daughters (aged eleven and fourteen), and myself - spend considerable time here. We're outdoor people, sometimes playing even in the rain. Occasionally, we barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with appetizing aromas.

The sound of lawnmowers is almost constant from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has abundant trees providing plenty of shade, though this means extensive leaf cleanup in autumn. The annual ritual of raking and burning leaves brings a pleasant scent that signals fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn.

With our garage at the rear of the house, we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working on my truck or other projects with the garage doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are particularly peaceful here, though Thanksgiving and other celebrations like Mother's Day and Christmas bring out-of-town visitors and extra parked cars throughout the neighborhood.

Overall, I'm content living here - it would be perfect if it weren't a through street.

I live in the heart of the high desert, where desert soil stretches as far as the eye can see. Unless you've lived here yourself, it's hard to understand what it's like being surrounded by endless brown landscapes, and when you do spot a green lawn, you know its owner is investing heavily in its maintenance.

When I first moved here in the 1990s, houses were few and far between. While that spacing largely remains today, there have been many new developments. The area is increasingly taking on an urban character, though this seems to be a common trend everywhere. The community is generally friendly, but like any developing area, it has its better and worse sections. My particular neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas.

The local businesses are primarily chain stores, such as Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel elsewhere, as we don't have establishments like Whole Foods. Construction appears to be the dominant industry here, though this isn't based on official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the area still is, with plenty of open space for new construction. This concerns me somewhat, as I appreciate the current atmosphere, having left a big city with no desire to return to that lifestyle.

Speaking of construction, that's my field - I work as a drywall and T-bar installer. One thing I particularly enjoy about living here is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, including its stark, unique beauty. The high desert's climate and landscape have created distinct ecosystems that require protection and house diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about their animal neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by the local lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside trying to catch various specimens. We have several local attractions, including the San Bernardino County Fair in Victorville, which offers a unique desert experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. For those interested in natural history and culture, the Victor Valley Museum showcases geological specimens, paleontological findings, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle the area's social and industrial development.

When describing my neighborhood, I believe my perspective is rather distinctive. Unlike most people who might describe traditional residential areas, my situation is quite different. My neighborhood is actually my college campus, with my primary community being those who live in my dormitory. I also consider the broader campus area as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree.

Despite this unconventional setting, my neighborhood shares many characteristics with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical community, mine has residential spaces, people, commercial areas, and recreational facilities. Let me first discuss our living spaces. There are three main types of housing in my immediate area: apartment complexes, traditional houses, and dormitories.

The apartments typically accommodate 2-4 residents per unit, with 4-6 units per floor in two-story buildings, housing approximately 20 people per building. There are also standalone houses available for rent to those affiliated with the institution, usually occupied by alumni, though these are fewer in number due to space efficiency concerns. The dormitories, which are the most prevalent form of housing, accommodate hundreds of students, typically with two students sharing a room.

Our community's population reflects the school's commitment to diversity. Residents span various cultures and age groups, with faculty and staff typically occupying the houses, newer students in dormitories, and upperclassmen in apartments. The community is too vibrant and diverse to be adequately captured in words alone.

As for amenities, our campus functions as a self-contained neighborhood with numerous stores and a central park. The commercial area features both typical dining establishments and campus-specific retail outlets, including clothing stores and grocers, ensuring all essential needs are met within our boundaries. Our park serves as a communal gathering space for our diverse population, maintained and secured through the collective effort of all community members.

In my neighborhood, there's a noticeable absence of sidewalks. The terrain slopes dramatically, and my house is situated at the peak of what locals call the "workout hill" - a popular challenge for joggers during their exercise routines. With no sidewalks on our street, pedestrians share the road with vehicles. The pavement is damaged in several spots, making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines crisscrossing our block look worn and patched, largely due to frequent storm damage that requires constant repairs.

Tall evergreens dominate the landscape, though they're not particularly beloved by residents who often remove them to preserve their ocean views. The houses here are strategically built on the hillside, featuring prominent second-story windows that cascade down the slope, each designed to capture the magnificent bay view. The sunsets are spectacular, with the water seeming to glow from within as the sky transforms into brilliant orange hues. However, cloudy weather prevails, filtering most sunlight through a persistent haze.

The damp climate encourages moss growth on virtually every surface - rooftops, vehicles, and handrails aren't spared. I once discovered this firsthand when my car developed a thick moss coating after being parked for just a month. The neighborhood demographics skew older, with retirees making up a significant portion of residents, despite a nearby school. Dogs are far more common than children here; they're often seen lounging in yards or playfully chasing each other down the street, sometimes even wandering into homes through open doors.

Wild rabbits are abundant, much to local gardeners' dismay as they damage plants and create burrows in lawns. My cats have become effective rabbit control in our immediate area. The local wildlife includes various birds - from tiny sparrows and hummingbirds to the occasional hawk or eagle, though the latter usually face harassment from territorial crows.

While there aren't any shops nearby, the waterfront below offers several restaurants specializing in fresh seafood. Though the beach is minimal, the rocky shoreline provides entertainment for stone-throwing enthusiasts. The bay itself is relatively narrow, with the opposite shore visible most days, even through the typical misty conditions.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, you'll find it easily accessible! Public transportation is convenient and remains one of New York City's primary modes of travel. Bensonhurst maintains its urban character, ensuring you still get that authentic New York City feel. Be prepared to encounter numerous Asian establishments throughout your visit. In the past twenty years, Bensonhurst has experienced a significant influx of Asian residents, resulting in Asian-owned businesses appearing on practically every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent, and these establishments are highly regarded by locals for their excellent food quality, competitive prices, and convenient locations. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian - it's a richly diverse community home to immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other attractions, including a newly renovated park featuring multiple basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, handball courts, playground equipment, and a water feature for children's summer enjoyment. True to New York City's character, the parks showcase remarkable diversity, with people from all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood is predominantly residential, featuring mostly two-family houses rather than corporate buildings, with some co-ops and condominiums. While the residents are generally friendly, noise can be an issue - expect to hear loud music from passing cars and revving engines, even in the early morning hours. Evening visitors should remain vigilant; while the area is relatively safe, there's always a possibility of encountering troublemakers, bullies, or thieves. Package theft has become a notable concern, and despite city regulations requiring pet owners to clean up after their dogs, compliance is inconsistent. You're likely to encounter pet waste on sidewalks during your morning commute or grocery runs, so watch your step and keep your footwear clean!

To understand Portland, Oregon, you must first grasp what "weird" truly means here. On the back of a multifunctional building - simultaneously housing a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club (operating in legally ambiguous ways) - you'll find the city's unofficial motto: "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this phrase echoes nostalgia for the Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, when the city was less renowned and more affordable, fostering unique creative communities. For others, it's an invitation: come to a place where being called weird is a badge of honor.

Despite the continuous influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of luxury condominiums to accommodate them, Portland maintains its peculiar character. Being weird here doesn't mean universal acceptance, but rather an openness to what others might reject. We face modern challenges and enjoy modern conveniences just like anywhere else - we too rely on Chinese imports. While there are countless ways to be unconventional, Portland also embraces the conventional. We have our share of yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and corporate professionals. Perhaps our "weirdness" lies in taking it all less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find vibrantly painted houses and street-side gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables. During summer, "free boxes" appear - containers filled with items their owners no longer want. These boxes, whether cardboard or plastic, often hold unexpected treasures for passersby, typically containing books and clothing, but sometimes surprising finds. This possibility of discovering something special while walking through Southeast Portland captures the city's essence - at least from my perspective, though I'm just one variety of weird among many.

Not everyone shares my enthusiasm for sidewalk treasures. Some prefer goat yoga (yes, that's yoga with actual goats) or cheering for the Timbers soccer team. Portland embraces diverse passions and dreamers, including those who actively pursue their dreams and those who contemplate them over one too many craft beers. The city faces challenges - drug problems often masking mental health issues, exacerbated by our notoriously gray, rainy weather. Our homeless crisis persists, drawing people seeking Portland's relatively better social services, though still inadequate. The housed population's response oscillates between compassion and contempt - in this regard, we're not so different from anywhere else.

The mountains stand eternal in the north, silent witnesses to each sunrise and sunset. Even when I'm too consumed by daily life to notice them, they remain steadfast and unmoved by the world's chaos. On my most troubled days, they command my attention, and when I turn to face them, they offer my restless spirit solace and the strength to persevere.

I first arrived here as an undergraduate student, and the northern mountains instantly captured my heart. While the university campus has its own magnificent features - the stunning architecture, serene ponds, and majestic trees - all of which I cherish, the mountains reign supreme in my affections.

The town itself is a treasure. Countless cafés have sheltered students during their caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown reveals historic charm in its weathered brick buildings housing restaurants and offices. Here, our seemingly quiet town pulses with urban energy, though this bustling atmosphere quickly gives way to tranquility beyond the library. This beautiful contrast of atmospheres creates an almost magical quality, inviting exploration and discovery.

Every corner of this place holds precious memories: from late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends to rushing through downtown streets to catch a university-sponsored movie at the elegant theater. Yet, like any place where life unfolds, it also harbors difficult memories. The ponds, particularly, have witnessed both quiet contemplation and tearful early-morning existential crises - the latter being something I know all too well.

Watching the pond's inhabitants - turtles, ducks, and insects - each playing their part in nature's grand design, I often questioned my own purpose and place in life's great mystery. During one such moment, I found myself walking past the pond, through the suburban neighborhoods, until I reached a main street. As the sun cast its golden light on the palm trees, painting the morning sky, I realized I was heading north. And there they were, as always - the mountains, their massive forms touching the dawn's hazy blue and amber horizon, silently inspiring me to persist, to endure, to continue forward.

At first glance, you might overlook this place - it's tucked behind a shopping center in what appears to be just another residential zone, somewhere you wouldn't expect to find much life. But venture past the shuttered Whole Foods and beyond the seasonally occupied hotels (save for the occasional summer family reunion), and you'll discover a vibrant community hiding in plain sight. Along these streets, you'll find several apartment complexes arranged with precision, like carefully separated Russian nesting dolls lined up along the road. While the first complex you encounter has a somewhat controversial reputation in local news (we'll skip those details - appearances can be misleading), the neighboring complexes reveal an entirely different world, one that remains largely unknown to most local residents.

Across the street stands a community college satellite campus, its quiet buildings keeping watch over the road as drowsy students drift in with their coffee at 7 AM. The iron gates creak open to welcome them while frustrated commuters honk and gesture on particularly busy days. The street intersects with another residential road, flanked by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center on the other, where patients recover from various injuries. The center features welcoming porch furniture and a gentle ceiling fan that stirs the thick summer air.

The park comes alive with children performing cartwheels on the grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retirees walk their dogs along the path, casting disapproving looks at skateboarding teens while politely acknowledging groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground, deep in conversation about boys and trending YouTube content. A nearby strip mall houses an affordable sushi restaurant that's mysteriously never crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon squeezed between them. It's the epitome of convenience - you could theoretically stock up on pool supplies, get your nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken all in one visit. The strip mall also features a self-serve frozen yogurt shop, frequently visited by local teens who clutch their topping-laden treats while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, convinced of their own coolness.

This neighborhood represents a quintessential slice of Americana - a preserved moment in the unhurried South where time seems to stand still, resistant to change.

My neighborhood has a unique character. While most houses are single-family dwellings, there are some that have been converted into duplexes while maintaining their connected structure. My house features a modest front yard and a small driveway on its left side. Like most homes here, it evokes memories of a recent past when suburban living embodied the American dream. Though this dream once united Americans, it seems to be fading now. Yet our neighborhood, along with many others, stands as a testament that this dream persists, even as we struggle to preserve it.

The residents may not share the same optimism of yesteryear, and the yard maintenance isn't quite what it used to be, but every driveway still holds a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings are their entire universe. The nearly century-old public school continues to inspire future generations while stirring memories in older residents. While churches are sparse and poorly attended, the basketball courts remain vibrant with activity. Despite their varied appearances, all homes share a similar spirit.

There's a Super "A" supermarket owned by a Yemeni family, perhaps the neighborhood's only Arab residents, in a predominantly African American community. The wide streets serve as impromptu football fields for children, who pause only for passing cars. Many residents are multi-generational, sharing stories of a time when the community was more closely knit.

A former karate school, which closed when martial arts movies lost their appeal, has become a pharmacy - because medications are supposedly the modern solution to everything. A small theater showing classic films at reduced prices survives, shunned by young people seeking newer releases but cherished by older residents seeking an affordable night out.

A single expressway runs through our town, though its access points lie in the neighboring municipality. A past proposal for a local exit was defeated when elders convinced the city council that it would harm the town's character, despite youth support. As we construct a new high school, we're debating a town mascot - I believe a cyborg cowboy with a log cabin would perfectly capture our town's essence.

Living in a major metropolitan area, my neighborhood exhibits remarkable diversity. The layout intermingles residential zones with commercial districts, creating a vibrant mix of businesses, offices, retail establishments, and entertainment venues. There's an endless array of dining options and shopping destinations to explore. While major corporate chains maintain a strong presence, boutique businesses are gaining popularity, appearing not only in shopping centers but also along streets that border otherwise peaceful residential areas.

The neighborhood features several parks that are popular among families with young children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with distinct communities coexisting in close proximity - including a thriving LGBTQ+ population, an Orthodox Jewish community, and immigrants from former Soviet states. The broader city hosts various ethnic enclaves, such as Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, though they're separated by what can be surprisingly long travel times despite relatively short distances.

Transportation is predominantly car-dependent, as walking isn't practical for most destinations despite some amenities being nearby. This reliance on vehicles contributes to severe traffic congestion and parking challenges. Recent years have seen extensive development, particularly in high-rise residential buildings, though this growth has sparked concerns among current residents about increasing population density and traffic.

The housing landscape is varied, ranging from single-family homes to duplexes and apartment complexes of different sizes. The population spans all age groups, though community bonds aren't as strong as they once were. I personally recall childhood memories of playing with neighboring kids, but such close community connections seem less common today.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed endless cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is all there is!" I replied, knowing she'd be shocked by the vast emptiness of the landscape. Coming from a place where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk away, she had never witnessed such expansive open space. Struck by the endless corn fields, I described my experience of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she truly understood my background and identity.

Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, beyond which lies my small residential community. The houses, primarily built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside Midwestern trees that transform with each season. The driveways showcase gleaming high-end Mercedes Benz vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun.

As you approach my grey stucco house, you'll often see my Korean neighbor, always wearing a friendly smile. He spends his days mowing his lawn, singing over the mower's drone. While the neighborhood finds him amusing, he's a genuinely wonderful person with a fascinating history. Though age has dulled some of his sharpness, this former doctor now peacefully blends into the landscape with his John Deere Zero Turn mower.

At my home, geese roam the side yard, pursued by our terrier. A small stream in the backyard flows to the quarry, accompanied by the sounds of bullfrogs, running water, and distant mooing from nearby farms. Across a handcrafted wooden bridge lies an untouched sanctuary of natural trees, herbs, and wildflowers - my childhood playground. Whether building tree forts or chasing wildlife, there was always adventure to be found, often shared with neighborhood friends.

Though winters here can be harsh, they possess their own beauty. The lush green yard transforms into a stark wilderness, and trees once adorned with vibrant flowers become bare silhouettes. Snowfall creates an overnight wonderland, the yard decorated with my little sister's snow angels and snowmen. During our childhood battles, we'd wage snowball wars from elaborate fort-like igloos reinforced with branches. In this magical realm, we lived in the moment, just children without worries, playing make-believe in our own private paradise.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located.
