More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist destinations. We don't have large shopping malls, Walmart, Target, or even Applebee's. Everything requires driving to reach. Nevertheless, I live in one of the world's most picturesque locations, surrounded by water. My "town" is nestled between the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find beaches to wade in everywhere you go.

My neighborhood embodies small-town charm. The houses aren't cramped together or built from identical designs. They're older homes, some renovated and some maintaining their original character, most with full basements visible from the street. Many houses sport classic aluminum siding, and the neighborhood is a rainbow of different colored homes. Most properties have yards featuring trampolines and play equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These homes represent the heart of Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already done so. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, cycle, and rollerblade. Neighbors know each other well enough to distinguish between residents and outsiders. You'll see people grilling outdoors and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away exchanging friendly smiles.

The properties are well-maintained, with no autumn leaves left unattended. Lawns are neatly mowed, and landscaping is kept trim. While it's not a neighborhood that immediately impresses with luxury homes, it strikes visitors as an ideal place to raise a family. It's peaceful, secure, and tranquil.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, and the city recycling center. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of game announcements. Our small town airport provides the background music of small planes taking off and landing. Residents can walk to the local ice cream shop and even downtown. Children can safely bike to the park about eight blocks away. It truly is an wonderful place to call home.

I live in what could be described as a typical suburban development, heavily regulated by a homeowners' association (HOA). The neighborhood features uniformly well-maintained single-family homes with similar front yard layouts - small grass areas, decorative stones, and compact driveways. You'll find occasional small trees dotting the landscape, and every home comes with a two-car garage.

The infrastructure is impeccable, with perfectly maintained concrete roads free of any defects. While most residences are single-story, there are some two-story homes scattered throughout. Rather than individual mailboxes, we have a centralized mail station system similar to apartment complexes, with secure individual boxes and package lockers - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our location sits on the city's outskirts, creating an interesting blend of suburban and rural characteristics. The community boasts extensive amenities, including multiple gated swimming pools accessible to all residents, and an extensive network of walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood itself is large enough to serve as an excellent circuit for exercise enthusiasts.

The demographic is predominantly retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a close-knit, safety-conscious community where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern convenities, including a modest but functional shopping mall. Most destinations require about a 15-minute drive, but once there, you'll find plenty of retail options ranging from upscale organic grocery stores to budget-friendly discount outlets.

In essence, our neighborhood epitomizes well-maintained suburban living with excellent amenities like pools and walking trails. While not immediately adjacent to shopping areas, we have convenient access to any major retail chain you might need within a reasonable driving distance.

I first learned about my current residence while listening to a podcast about missing persons cases. It was rather unexpected, considering nearly every apartment in this area commands rent exceeding a thousand dollars monthly. Neither I nor any of my acquaintances had ever heard this particular story before. Perhaps it's the daily struggle that defines our lives here. I know several friends who weep at night from the stress. While everything is costly, we've become adept at living frugally over time. You learn to appreciate the musty scent of second-hand toys and vintage clothing. Your sense of smell seems to dull with age. You might take up smoking, or perhaps you just become desensitized to your surroundings. But the flea market atmosphere is ever-present. Adulthood smells like dusty magazines piled on an unused piano, a scent that permeates leather and persists even after washing.

In this neighborhood, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the furthest point, you can visit two charitable thrift shops, a library, a bookstore specializing in rare editions, and an antique shop. The downtown area is crowded, with vehicles and pedestrians filling the streets each morning, yet the thrift stores remain oddly peaceful. Despite the bustle outside, silence reigns within. It's an ideal place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more people and vehicles. They call it a growing city. Despite hosting one of the largest e-commerce and delivery companies' headquarters, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York - everyone pursues their own objectives without much interference from others. You can maintain your solitude and independence, and others will respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a cultural norm, people here don't intrude into others' lives.

You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, while the city ebbs and flows around you like ocean waves. It's a vibrant environment. Between my pianist neighbor and the two aspiring singers upstairs, there's constant activity. We've evolved from being mere apartment dwellers into a genuine community. We unite for our needs, share in celebrations and sorrows, and support each other when possible. I consider myself fortunate to be here. I appreciate my neighbors, and they treat me well. We maintain cleanliness and share food reciprocally. We help with mail delivery and enjoy each other's company. Though I reside in an enormous, seemingly impersonal urban expanse, it's neighbors like these who make me feel that I haven't made a mistake with my life choices.

I live in a small Midwestern town located just beyond the suburban areas of a major city. My neighborhood, situated on the east side of town, could be considered the most economically challenged area. Property values here are low, with most houses either rented or owned by low-income residents. However, the area isn't unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly, offering smiles and greetings when I walk down the street.

While crime rates are slightly higher than in other parts of town, they remain relatively low overall. In the past decade, there have been several violent incidents within a few blocks of my home, including some shootings and at least one homicide. Our next-door neighbors tragically lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar last year. Fortunately, our family has only experienced minor issues, such as occasionally having items disappear from our porch when we forget to bring them inside.

Like many parts of America, our town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. Thankfully, our community offers various resources to combat this issue, including several rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for families and friends of those affected by addiction.

Despite these challenges, our town has many positive aspects. The elementary school my son attends has exceptional staff at all levels. Although he has special needs, the school's positive environment has protected him from bullying, and he truly loves being there. We have an active PTO that organizes various events throughout the year to encourage family engagement and educational achievement. Given that over 20% of our town's population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free meals to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. No family is stigmatized for financial limitations, and school-related expenses are kept reasonable.

The City Council has made numerous improvements to the town's appearance, including road repairs, landscaping, and park renovations. However, these improvements have primarily focused on the town center and western areas, where shopping districts and main traffic routes are located. The east side, where I reside, tends to receive less attention, which frustrates many in our neighborhood.

Overall, I find life here satisfying. The community is friendly, the schools are excellent, shopping options are adequate, and while our home may not have high monetary value, it's comfortable and meets our needs. Having lived here for over 16 years, we couldn't imagine calling anywhere else home.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural vitality, perched atop a hill and embraced by historically significant buildings. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, and down the slope sits a charming arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. During June and July weekends especially, queues of people regularly form outside.

A few blocks uphill lies the city park, surprisingly spacious for its urban location. Concrete walls with broad steps encircle the park. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalks and wide steps. While snow is rare, the heavy winter rains make staying warm a challenge. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in the outskirts, they find better warmth and maintain convenient access to the area's only family center where they can maintain personal hygiene.

What captivates me about this city isn't just its historic charm - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's cultural fabric that truly moves me. Hilltop, once notorious across the West Coast for gang activity, still echoes with stories of federal and DEA interventions from three decades past. These narratives live on, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself.

Despite its reputation as one of the city's rougher areas, residents work diligently to maintain their neighborhood. While some warn white people against walking here after dark, I see this caution as a remnant of old prejudices and social conditioning. Perhaps it's because I'm ethnically ambiguous enough not to appear entirely white, or maybe Hilltop accepts me as one of its own - someone equally conscious of our nation's ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions, even in a supposedly diverse urban utopia.

One thing remains certain: Hilltop is home, regardless of where life takes me. I feel truly alive on these streets at night, encountering people more likely to offer me their jacket than cause harm. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours so I can charge my phone during rainstorms, where strangers notice me in my lowest moments against store frontages on gloomy nights, offering not just money but affirming words about my worth and beauty.

I moved into this neighborhood just before starting eighth grade. Initially, making friends was challenging, but I eventually became close with someone living two houses down and another person on my street. Though they've since moved away, the memories remain. Most of the original residents from when I first arrived still live here. My neighborhood is typical of American suburbs, featuring numerous two-story homes. During weekends and warm weather, you can hear children playing outside. The area remains peaceful most days. I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors. People here respect your privacy unless you need assistance. I've received many online deliveries and never had a package stolen from my porch, which speaks to the trustworthiness of my neighbors.

There's a park just a couple minutes from my house, filled with countless memories. I've played various sports there - basketball, football, and baseball - with neighborhood friends. While I did have one unfortunate incident where I got elbowed in the nose during football, the positive memories far outweigh the negative ones. These days, I mainly visit the park with my cousin's children, who, being much younger, still enjoy playground equipment like swings and slides. Their excitement about going to the park is infectious, and the place now fills me with nostalgia for many different reasons.

The neighborhood boasts impressive diversity, especially in terms of cuisine. Within just a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, though many people now prefer using delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food establishments are particularly popular, as they are in most suburban areas, and there are numerous pizza options. The neighborhood offers all essential amenities, including multiple dry cleaners, both Walgreens and CVS pharmacies, and a Midwest-favorite Jewel-Osco grocery store. There's even an Indian grocery store for those interested in authentic Indian ingredients or prepared foods.

Overall, I truly appreciate my neighborhood. When I read about neighbor disputes and problems on social media and in the news, I feel particularly grateful for my community.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is one of the main reasons I enjoy living there. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered throughout. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier now, but the service and drinks are still decent. The community is quite diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, owing to the affordable housing options.

There's a lively presence of children in the area due to an elementary school within walking distance. While I don't know my neighbors personally (and prefer it that way), there's an amusing situation where management installed an air freshener outside one apartment due to frequent cannabis use - something my boyfriend and I find rather entertaining.

The surrounding buildings are generally older, though some have updated interiors. Further down the street, there are new apartment complexes, but I'm skeptical of their construction quality. They charge premium rates despite their questionable build quality, taking advantage of their proximity to campus.

The neighborhood has its quirks - there's an incredibly cheap restaurant nearby serving microwaved food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. However, recent city funding has improved the area with new sidewalks and landscaping. My building is surrounded by trees, though some have been removed, creating a notably greener environment compared to other parts of the street.

The contrast between streets is striking - while I live on 42nd Street, the parallel 43rd Street behind us is noticeably more run-down, with deteriorating infrastructure and buildings hidden behind dense tree coverage. While there have been crime issues in certain complexes, including some across from my building, I generally feel content here. The affordable rent, convenient amenities, walkable distance to the university, and easy access to public transportation make it a practical and satisfying place to live.

I live in a unique neighborhood of duplexes arranged along a cul-de-sac. The buildings are strategically placed to resemble single-family homes, unified by their yellow exteriors, white porches, and green metal roofs. The community is remarkably close-knit, with most residents maintaining friendly relationships. On many evenings, we gather spontaneously at the end of driveways to chat while neighborhood children play with toys, draw with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's a refreshing contrast to today's technology-dominated world, almost like stepping into the past.

Our community is embraced by fields and forests, set against a backdrop of blue skies and floating white clouds. The only drawback? This season brought tornado warnings, and recently, we experienced our first real tornado siren alert. I found myself seeking shelter in my bathtub, clutching my small dog, purse, and some pillows, while my larger dog, anxious and barking, refused to leave the living room. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of heavy hail. After the storm, steam rose from the roads as the temperature dramatically dropped from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hot pavement instantly melted the hail. As the skies cleared, a magical moment occurred - the sun emerged during the rain, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos to share with friends and family on Facebook, leaving everyone amazed.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until residents returned from their storm shelters, after which normal life resumed - mothers and children outdoors as dinner prepared. As someone who recently relocated from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I find this friendly neighborhood charming, particularly the Southern accents. While all units are two-bedroom, two-bath duplexes with identical exteriors, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some being quite compact.

I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home to visit the decorative pond. The area is rich with wildlife - deer frequent the area, and mornings are marked by the deep croaking of bullfrogs. Located just forty minutes from Charlotte, this location offers the perfect blend of rural and urban life. Each day begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, creating the atmosphere of a small village community. We even have a neighborhood donkey whose evening braying serves as a familiar reminder of our rural setting. I consider myself fortunate to have discovered this wonderful community.

Having lived here for about a decade, I feel qualified to share my experience. When I first moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was honestly heartbroken. I shed tears because I missed my old community deeply. However, my parents made this decision for better opportunities - improved housing, superior schools, and generally a more upscale neighborhood for me and my younger sister.

As time passed, I adapted to my new environment, making both friends and rivals at school. While I remained somewhat distant from most neighbors, I formed meaningful connections with Mr. Glen's family and Dennis, who lived next door. They've become almost like extended family to me. A particularly memorable moment was attending Mr. Glen's second marriage to Ms. Veda. It was a joyous celebration where I caught the garter (though missed the bouquet!), and danced the night away, especially enjoying time with their daughter Marsharii, whom I haven't seen since but hope is thriving wherever she is.

The neighborhood itself is quite intricate, though GPS now helps me explore it more confidently. I have fond memories of gaming sessions with my friends Kason and Curtis, making the most of our youth. I often find solace in the local park, where I practice balance exercises with sticks from Home Depot and sometimes bring my wooden bokken sword - it's my way of pursuing my interests. The community also offers basketball and tennis courts, and while I haven't used them recently, their presence is comforting. Tennis especially holds a special place in my heart, as my father and Mr. Graves coached my best friend and me - tough sessions, but always enjoyable.

Looking back, this neighborhood has given me countless memorable experiences, and I'm optimistic that even better moments await in the future!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. While it may not particularly stand out among other South Carolina towns, it plays a crucial role in the agricultural industry. Johnston proudly calls itself the Peach Capital of the World, as displayed on its welcome sign. The area is predominantly farmland, filled with peach orchards and cattle ranches.

Houses outside the town center are generously spaced apart, typically two stories high with either metal roofing to combat the intense summer heat or traditional gray shingles. Most homes are set back from the road, leaving front fields available for livestock or crops.

The town center features a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all local businesses are concentrated. For dining options, there are three choices: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A pizza place once operated here but recently closed.

The town has several notable businesses: Maxwell and Halford Drug, a family-owned pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola; IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), a small but relatively expensive grocery store; and Dollar General, which is arguably the most popular store in town, offering various daily necessities and staying busy throughout its operating hours.

Other businesses include Possibilities Furniture & More, a long-standing furniture store run by a well-respected community member offering delivery services, and Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming facility providing various animal care services. Both medical and veterinary services are available in quieter areas of town, with small but well-equipped practices serving local residents.

Johnston Elementary School serves the younger students, though children must travel to the neighboring town for middle and high school education. While the town currently lacks parks, there are plans to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance family activities and attract visitors and potential residents.

Though the town lacks entertainment venues like movie theaters, bowling alleys, hangout spots, playgrounds, dog parks, or diverse dining options, it maintains its charm as a small, close-knit community - one so modest you might miss it if you blink while driving through!

I reside in a typical suburban area of a small Tennessee town in the South. Our street connects two state highways, which brings more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise, it's a peaceful neighborhood. There isn't much turnover in residents, so I've become familiar with most of my neighbors. People generally keep themselves occupied with yard maintenance and daily routines. During winter, children enjoy sledding down the hill on our side street. Our house sits at the corner of the street, giving us a clear view of all the comings and goings, and we're familiar with the vehicles our neighbors drive. We tend to notice when unfamiliar cars appear.

Some residents take walks for exercise or walk their dogs, while children ride their bikes and play as you'd expect. Since we work from home, our family of four - my wife, our two daughters (ages eleven and fourteen), and myself - are often present. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in the rain, and occasionally barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with delightful cooking aromas.

The sound of lawnmowers is nearly constant from March through October, when the grass finally stops growing. Our neighborhood, originally wooded, has many trees providing ample shade, though this means considerable leaf cleanup in autumn. The annual ritual of raking and burning leaves brings a pleasant scent that signals fall's arrival. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn.

With our garage at the rear of the house, we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working on my truck or other projects with the garage doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are generally quiet, though Thanksgiving and other celebrations like Mother's Day and Christmas bring out-of-town visitors and extra parked cars throughout the area.

Overall, I enjoy living here - if only it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless expanses of dirt. Unless you've actually lived here, it's hard to comprehend the constant sight of brown landscapes, and when you do spot a green lawn, you know its owner is investing heavily in maintenance. When I first moved here in the 1990s, houses were few and far between. While that spacing remains similar today, there have been many new developments. The area is increasingly urbanizing, though this seems to be a common trend everywhere.

The community is generally friendly, but like any city, it has its better and worse areas. My particular neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local businesses are primarily chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel elsewhere, as we don't have establishments like Whole Foods.

Construction appears to be the dominant industry here, though I'm not citing official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the area still is, with plenty of open space for building. This prospect concerns me somewhat, as I appreciate the current atmosphere, having left a big city with no desire to return. Coincidentally, I work in construction as a drywall and T-bar installer.

One of my favorite aspects of living here is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, particularly its stark, unique beauty. The high desert's climate and landscape have created distinct ecosystems that require protection and house diverse wildlife. Residents should educate themselves about their animal neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside attempting to catch various specimens. We have several local attractions, including the San Bernardino County Fair, which offers a genuine Victorville experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. The Victor Valley Museum showcases the area's natural history through geological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that chronicle Victorville's social and industrial development.

When describing my neighborhood, I believe my perspective is rather unique. Unlike most people who might describe traditional residential areas, my situation is quite different. I consider my college campus to be my neighborhood, with my dormitory community forming the core of my social environment, and the broader campus serving as my extended neighborhood.

Despite this unconventional setting, my campus neighborhood shares many similarities with traditional neighborhoods. Like any typical community, we have residential spaces, a diverse population, commercial establishments, and recreational areas.

The residential spaces in my neighborhood come in three distinct forms. First, there are apartment-style buildings where typically 2-4 people share a unit, with 4-6 units per floor across two floors, housing approximately 20 residents per building. Second, we have traditional houses available for rent to those affiliated with the institution, usually occupied by alumni in 2-4 bedroom arrangements, though these are less common. Third, and most prevalent, are the dormitory buildings, each housing hundreds of students, typically with two students sharing a room.

Our community takes pride in its diversity, featuring residents from various cultural backgrounds and age groups. Faculty and staff typically occupy the houses, while newer students reside in dormitories, and upperclassmen tend to live in apartments.

The neighborhood is essentially self-sufficient, featuring numerous stores and a central park. Our commercial area includes various dining options alongside campus-specific retail outlets for clothing and groceries, ensuring residents can find everything they need within the community. The park serves as a communal gathering space, maintained through the collective effort of community members, providing a safe and clean environment for recreation and social interaction.

In my neighborhood, sidewalks are scarce. The terrain slopes dramatically, with my house perched at the summit of the steepest incline in the area - a hill that's earned the nickname "workout hill" among local joggers who challenge themselves on it daily. Without sidewalks, pedestrians share the road, which has developed some troublesome potholes over time. The utility lines crisscrossing our streets look rather worn, frequently damaged by falling branches during our numerous storms, resulting in a patchwork of repairs.

Towering evergreens dominate the landscape, though they're not particularly beloved by residents who prefer unobstructed ocean views. This explains the architectural trend of tall houses with expansive glass facades on their upper levels, each one positioned to capture the magnificent bay vista. The sunsets are particularly stunning, with the water appearing to glow from within as the sky blazes orange, though such clear views are often filtered through our prevalent cloud cover.

The damp climate encourages moss growth on virtually every surface - roofs, vehicles, and handrails aren't spared. I learned this firsthand when my car developed a thick moss coating after just one month of sitting idle.

The demographic skews older, with retirees making up much of the population despite a nearby school. Dogs, rather than children, rule the neighborhood. They roam freely, occasionally wandering into unlocked homes - I've had to escort an uninvited canine visitor out of my living room before. Wild rabbits are abundant, much to local gardeners' dismay, though my cats have effectively reduced their population in our immediate vicinity. The local bird life includes sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional raptor, which rarely stays long before being driven away by territorial crows.

While there's no shopping district nearby, the waterfront offers several seafood restaurants for those willing to make the downhill trek. The shoreline is rocky rather than sandy, perfect for stone-throwing, and the relatively narrow bay allows clear views of the opposite shore, even through our characteristic mist.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you'll find it easily accessible! Public transportation is excellent and remains one of New York City's primary modes of travel. Bensonhurst maintains its urban character, giving you that authentic New York City feel. Be prepared to encounter numerous Asian establishments throughout the area. In the past twenty years, Bensonhurst has experienced a significant influx of Asian residents, resulting in Asian-owned businesses appearing on practically every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent, and these establishments are highly regarded by locals for their exceptional food quality, competitive prices, and convenient locations. In my immediate vicinity alone, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian - it's a richly diverse community home to immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other amenities, including a recently upgraded park featuring ten basketball courts, a spacious field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, playground equipment, and a water feature for children's summer enjoyment. True to New York City's character, the parks reflect the area's diversity, with people of all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood architecture consists mainly of residential buildings rather than corporate structures, predominantly featuring two-family houses alongside some co-ops and condominiums. While the residents are generally friendly, noise can be an issue - expect to hear loud music from passing cars and the occasional revving engine, especially in the morning hours.

Evening visitors should exercise standard urban precautions. Though the neighborhood is relatively safe, like any urban area, it has its share of troublemakers, bullies, and petty criminals. Package theft has become a concern, and despite city regulations regarding pet waste cleanup, some dog owners unfortunately ignore these rules, making it necessary to watch your step while walking around the neighborhood.

To truly understand Portland, Oregon, you must first grasp what "weird" means here. The city's unofficial motto, displayed on a building that houses an eclectic mix of businesses - a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club (some operating in legally grey areas) - proudly declares "Keep Portland Weird." For some locals, this phrase evokes nostalgia for the Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, when the city was less renowned and more affordable, fostering unique creative communities. For others, it's an invitation: come to Portland, where being called weird is a badge of honor.

Despite the recent influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of luxury condos to accommodate them, Portland maintains its distinctive character. Being weird here doesn't mean universal acceptance, but rather an openness to what society typically rejects. We still face modern challenges and enjoy modern conveniences - like everyone else, we rely on imported goods. While there are countless ways to be unconventional, Portland has its share of normalcy too, with its yoga studios, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps our "weirdness" simply lies in taking life less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find vibrantly painted houses, street-side gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and "free boxes" during summer months. These boxes (or bags) contain donated items, often creating serendipitous moments when passersby find unexpected treasures. While typically filled with clothes and books, anything might appear in these boxes. This possibility for magic while walking through Southeast Portland captures the essence of the city - at least from my perspective, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands.

Not everyone embraces sidewalk shopping, of course. Some prefer goat yoga (yes, that's exactly what it sounds like) or cheering for the Timbers soccer team. Portland is a mosaic of passionate people pursuing various interests and dreams - or sometimes just discussing those dreams over craft beers. The city faces real challenges too: drug problems (often rooted in mental health issues, possibly exacerbated by our notoriously grey, rainy weather) and homelessness. The latter draws people seeking Portland's relatively better social services, though like everywhere else, these prove inadequate. Local attitudes toward the homeless oscillate between compassion and contempt - in this aspect, we're not so weird after all.

The mountains stand eternal in the north, silent witnesses to each sunrise and sunset. Even when I'm too consumed by daily life to notice them, they remain steadfast and unmoved by the world's chaos. On my most troubled days, they command my attention, and when I turn to face them, they offer my restless spirit solace and the strength to persevere.

I first arrived here as an undergraduate student, and the northern mountains immediately captured my heart. While the university campus boasts its own beautiful features - stunning architecture, serene ponds, and majestic trees - all of which I cherish, the mountains reign supreme in my affections.

The town itself is a treasure trove of charm. Countless cafés have hosted my marathon study sessions, and a short walk or bus ride to downtown reveals historic buildings with their weathered brick facades housing restaurants and offices. This section pulses with urban energy, rivaling the neighboring city's vitality. Yet, past the library, the atmosphere shifts back to tranquil small-town life. This fascinating contrast between urban buzz and small-town peace creates an enchanting environment that begs to be discovered.

Every corner of this place holds precious memories: from late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends to rushed trips downtown for university-sponsored movies at the elegant theater. Of course, it also harbors some painful memories - such is life. The campus ponds, particularly, have witnessed both quiet contemplation and early-morning crying sessions during existential crises - the latter being more frequent in my experience.

Watching the pond's inhabitants - turtles, ducks, and insects - each playing their part in nature's grand design, I often questioned my own purpose and place in life's great mystery. One day, walking past the pond, through suburban streets lined with modest homes, I reached a main road just as sunrise painted the sky. The sun's rays illuminated the palm trees, and as I looked up, I realized I was facing north. There they were, as always - the mighty mountains touching the dawn's blue and golden sky, silently inspiring me to keep moving forward, to persist despite all obstacles.

At first glance, you might miss it - after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, where one wouldn't expect to find livable spaces. At least, not the kind where most people would want to live. But if you venture behind the abandoned Whole Foods and past the hotels that sit mostly vacant except for occasional summer family reunions, you'll discover a vibrant community. Within these neighborhoods, along these streets, stand several apartment complexes - arranged like Russian nesting dolls that have been meticulously unpacked and lined up along the road. The first apartments you encounter have made headlines for some unsavory incidents, so we'll skip those - appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the complexes next to it, and the two beyond that, represent a hidden world that few local residents know exists.

Across from these complexes sits a community college satellite campus - a quiet, drowsy collection of buildings standing guard by the road, where students drift in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 AM as they begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists and grumble about traffic delays on high-attendance days. The road forms a T-intersection with another residential street, flanked by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for unfortunate fracture patients on the other. The rehab center features cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan that stirs the thick summer air. Children run and cartwheel across the prickly grass in the park across the street, while bees drift lazily among the roadside flower beds. Retired seniors walk their dogs along the path, scowling at skateboarding teenagers while politely nodding to groups of teenage girls gathered near the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations.

In the strip mall beside the park, there's an affordable sushi restaurant that never seems too busy, a swimming supply store next door, and a nail salon nestled between them. You could stock up on pool supplies, get a manicure, and enjoy hibachi chicken all at once - that's the charm of a strip mall. There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop where you often see teens from the park clutching cups topped with various toppings while performing skateboard tricks and vaping, believing it makes them look cool. This neighborhood represents a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy South where hardly anything changes, not even time itself.

My neighborhood has a unique character. While most houses are designed for single families, there are some interesting split-level homes that remain connected as one structure. My house features a modest front yard and a small driveway on its left side. Like others in the area, it's a testament to the not-so-distant past when suburban living embodied the American dream. Though that dream seems to be fading nationally, our neighborhood, along with many others, stands as a living reminder that some still cherish and pursue it.

The residents may not share the same optimism of yesteryear, and the yard maintenance might have declined, but every driveway still hosts a car or two, and children still play as if their immediate surroundings are their entire universe. The nearly century-old public school continues to inspire future generations while evoking memories for older residents. While churches are sparse and poorly attended, the basketball courts remain vibrant with activity. Despite their varied appearances, all homes share a similar spirit.

A large supermarket called "Super A," owned by what might be the neighborhood's only Arab family from Yemen, serves the predominantly African American community. The wide streets often serve as impromptu football fields, with games pausing only for passing cars. Many residents are multi-generational, carrying stories of a time when the community was more closely knit.

The former karate school, a casualty of waning martial arts movie popularity, has transformed into a pharmacy - because medication is supposedly the modern solution to everything. A small theater showing classic films at reasonable prices survives, shunned by youth seeking newer releases but embraced by older residents seeking an evening out without children.

A single expressway passes through town, though its access points lie in the neighboring municipality. A previous proposal for a local exit was defeated when elders convinced the city council that it would compromise the town's character, despite youth support. As we construct a new high school, the community debates its mascot - personally, I believe a cyborg cowboy with a log cabin would perfectly capture our town's essence.

Living in a major metropolitan area, my neighborhood exhibits remarkable diversity. The layout interweaves residential zones with commercial districts in what appears to be a random pattern, featuring various businesses ranging from office spaces to retail shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's an abundance of dining options and shopping opportunities. While major corporate chains maintain a strong presence, boutique businesses are gaining popularity, appearing not only in shopping centers but also along streets that border otherwise peaceful residential areas.

The neighborhood features several parks that are popular among families with young children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with distinct communities coexisting in close proximity - including a vibrant LGBTQ+ population, an Orthodox Jewish community, and immigrants from former Soviet states. The broader city hosts various ethnic enclaves like Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, though they're separated by what can be surprisingly long travel times despite relatively short distances. A mere 10-mile journey can take up to two hours during peak traffic periods.

Despite the walkable proximity of many amenities, most residents rely on cars for transportation, contributing to severe traffic congestion and parking difficulties. Recent years have seen extensive development, particularly in high-rise residential buildings, though this growth has met with mixed reactions from current residents concerned about increasing population density and traffic.

Housing options vary considerably, from single-family homes to duplexes, small apartment complexes, and condominiums, offering diverse living arrangements within the same neighborhood. The community includes residents of all ages, though modern urban life has somewhat diminished the close-knit neighborhood relationships of the past. I personally recall childhood memories of playing with neighboring kids, but today I barely know most of my neighbors - a reflection of how community dynamics have evolved in urban settings.

"What's out here?" she asked as we drove past the endless cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is everything!" I replied, knowing she'd be shocked by the vast emptiness of the landscape. Coming from a place where she could walk to the grocery store in five minutes, she had never experienced such open space before. Noticing her amazement at the endless cornfields, I began sharing stories of my upbringing in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she truly understood my background and identity.

Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, beyond which lies my small residential community. The homes here are primarily brick and stucco, each situated on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside seasonal Midwestern trees. The driveways showcase gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun.

As you approach my grey stucco house, you'll often see my Korean neighbor, always wearing a friendly smile as he mows his lawn, singing over the engine's drone. While the neighborhood finds him amusing, he's a genuinely wonderful person with a fascinating history. Though age has dulled some of his sharpness, this former doctor has become one with his John Deere Zero Turn mower and his beloved lawn.

At my home, geese roam the side yard, constantly pursued by our terrier. A small stream in the backyard flows toward the quarry, accompanied by the sounds of bullfrogs and distant mooing from nearby farms.
