Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
I live in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan, where farmland transitions into small tourist cities. We don't have large shopping malls, Walmart, Target, or even Applebee's. You need to drive everywhere you want to go. Nevertheless, I live in one of the world's most beautiful locations, surrounded by water. My "city" is nestled between the magnificent Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. You can find beaches to dip your toes in everywhere you go.

My neighborhood embodies the essence of small-town life. The houses aren't cramped together or built from the same cookie-cutter design. They're older homes, some renovated and updated, others maintaining their original character. Most have full basements visible from the street, and many feature classic aluminum siding. The houses in our area display every color imaginable. Most properties have yards where you'll find trampolines and playground equipment. Some residents maintain gardens and have fenced areas for their pets.

These homes represent Middle America - hardworking people making a living, either raising families or having already raised them. Children play in the streets daily, while people walk their dogs, ride bikes, or rollerblade. Neighbors know each other well enough to recognize who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see people grilling outdoors and waving, or dog walkers from a few blocks away exchanging pleasant smiles.

The properties are well-maintained, with no leftover fall leaves, neatly mowed lawns, and properly trimmed bushes and plants. While it's not the kind of neighborhood that makes you marvel at luxurious homes, it's one that makes you think, "This would be a great place to raise a family." It's peaceful, quiet, and safe - representing what many people want: a secure haven to return to at day's end.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department and jail, the health department, and the city recycling center. Nearby baseball and softball fields fill the air with the sound of announcers calling games. Our small town airport provides the background music of small planes taking off and landing. You can walk to the local ice cream shop, and even downtown if you're ambitious. My children can bike to the park, just eight blocks away. It truly is an wonderful place to call home.

I live in what could be described as a typical suburban development with a strong homeowners' association (HOA) presence. Upon entering our neighborhood, you'll notice uniformly maintained single-family homes, all adhering to HOA standards. The front yards follow a consistent pattern - modest grass areas, decorative stones, and compact driveways, with occasional small trees dotting the landscape. Every home features a two-car garage.

The neighborhood infrastructure is impeccable, with well-maintained concrete roads free of any deterioration. While most residences are single-story, you'll occasionally find two-story homes. Rather than individual mailboxes, we have a centralized mail station system similar to apartment complexes, with secure individual boxes and package lockers - another example of the HOA's preference for uniformity.

Our location sits at the city's periphery, creating an interesting blend of suburban and rural characteristics. The development boasts extensive amenities, including multiple gated community pools accessible to all residents, and an extensive network of walking trails perfect for dog walking or evening strolls. The neighborhood itself is large enough to serve as an exercise circuit without needing to visit external parks.

The community demographic primarily consists of retirees, with a smaller mixture of middle-aged residents and young professionals. It's a close-knit, security-conscious environment where neighbors look out for each other. While our city is surprisingly populous, it maintains a small-town atmosphere. We have access to most modern convenities, including a modest but functional mall. Most destinations require about a 15-minute drive, but once there, you'll find plenty of retail options ranging from premium organic grocery stores to budget-friendly discount outlets.

Overall, our neighborhood embodies suburban comfort - safe, well-maintained, and conventional. While not immediately adjacent to shopping areas, we enjoy excellent amenities like community pools and walking trails, with easy driving access to any major retail establishment you might need.

I first learned about my place while listening to a podcast about missing persons cases. It was quite unexpected. Most apartments in this area were renting for over a thousand dollars monthly. I had never heard this story before, and neither had any of my friends. Perhaps it's the daily struggle. I know several friends who cry themselves to sleep. Life is expensive, but over the years, we've learned to live frugally. You grow accustomed to the musty scent of flea market toys and second-hand clothes. Your sense of smell seems to dull with age. You might take up smoking, or maybe you just become desensitized to everything. But the flea market atmosphere is always present. Adulthood smells like dusty magazines piled on an unused piano. The scent seeps into leather and lingers even after washing.

In this neighborhood, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. Starting from the far end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare bookstore, and an antique shop. Downtown is crowded, with cars and people filling the streets each morning, but inside the thrift stores, it's always quiet. No matter how much activity passes by outside, silence reigns within. It's a perfect place to while away an afternoon. Each year brings more people and traffic. They call it a developing city. Housing one of the largest e-commerce and delivery companies' headquarters, it's still experiencing growing pains. It reminds me of New York - everyone focuses on their own goals, and nobody demands much from you. You can maintain your solitude and independence, and people respect that. Unlike the South, where showing concern is a sign of caring, people here don't intrude into others' lives.

You can maintain your privacy as long as you wish, and the city ebbs and flows around you like ocean waves. It's a vibrant place. Between the pianist next door and two aspiring singers upstairs, there's always something happening. Rather than being just apartment dwellers, we've become a community of friends. We unite for our needs, celebrate birthdays together, share in grief, and help each other when possible. I feel fortunate to be here. I appreciate my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to clean up after myself and share food with them, and they do the same. We exchange mail and greetings. It's pleasant to see them, and I believe the feeling is mutual. Though I live in a vast, impersonal urban landscape, it's neighbors like these who make me feel like I haven't completely misstepped in life.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburban boundaries of a major city. I live in the eastern district, which is considered the most economically challenged area of our community. While property values here are modest, with most residences occupied by lower-income families either as renters or owners, the area maintains its own charm. The residents are typically warm and welcoming, often exchanging friendly greetings during neighborhood walks.

Although crime rates are marginally higher than in other parts of town, they remain relatively low overall. In the past decade, there have been several serious incidents within blocks of my home, including some shootings and one homicide. Tragically, our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting incident near a local bar last year. Our family has been fortunate to experience only minor issues, such as occasional theft of items left unattended on our porch.

Like many American communities, our town has been significantly impacted by the opioid crisis, with numerous lives lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, the community has responded with various support systems, including rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for affected families.

Despite these challenges, our town has numerous strengths. The local elementary school, where my son attends, boasts exceptional staff at all levels. My son, who has special needs, thrives in the school's positive environment and has been free from bullying. The school's parent-teacher organization is very active, organizing various events throughout the year. Given that over 20% of our population lives below the poverty line, the school provides free meals to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry. The school system treats all families with equal dignity, keeping educational expenses affordable.

The municipal government has made significant improvements to the town's infrastructure and aesthetics, though these enhancements have primarily focused on the town center and western areas, where commercial activity is concentrated. The eastern section, where I reside, often receives less attention, causing some frustration among residents.

Nevertheless, I find this town a satisfying place to call home. The community is welcoming, the educational system is strong, and there's adequate retail variety to meet our needs. While our house may not be highly valued in monetary terms, it provides a comfortable living space. After 16 years here, we've become deeply rooted in this community and couldn't imagine living elsewhere.

My neighborhood pulses with cultural richness, perched atop a hill and embraced by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment complex directly opposite the historic theater, with a charming arcade bar just down the slope that attracts diverse crowds on balmy summer evenings. During June and July weekends, you'll often spot queues of people eagerly waiting to enter. A few blocks uphill lies the city park, surprisingly spacious for its urban setting. The park is bordered by concrete walls with broad steps carved into them. During the harsh winter months, homeless individuals arrange their tents in orderly rows along the sidewalks and wide steps. While snow is rare, the winter rains are heavy, making it challenging to stay warm. By clustering their tents in the city center rather than in outlying areas, they find better warmth and remain within walking distance of the region's only family center where they can access bathing facilities.

What captivates me about my city isn't just its historic charm - the majestic buildings and varied architecture cascading down hillsides toward the ocean. Rather, it's the community's spirit that truly moves me. Hilltop was once infamous along the West Coast for gang activity. Even thirty years later, stories circulate about federal agents and DEA operations sweeping through the area. These memories endure, passed down through generations and shared with newcomers like myself. Despite still being considered one of the city's tougher neighborhoods, residents work diligently to maintain their community. They remain deeply invested in their neighborhood's welfare.

There's a common warning that white people shouldn't walk these streets after dark, but I see this as an echo of the past, tainted by social prejudices. Perhaps it's because my complexion allows me to blend in, or maybe because Hilltop recognizes me as someone who understands the ongoing struggles with racism, cultural bias, and fear-based assumptions - even in a city that aspires to be a multicultural haven.

One thing is certain: Hilltop is my home, regardless of where life takes me. I feel alive traversing these streets at night, encountering people who are more likely to offer me their jacket than cause harm. It's where laundromat owners extend their hours so I can charge my phone during rainy weather. It's where, on the gloomiest nights, while I sat feeling invisible against store fronts, strangers have stopped to look me in the eye, offer me five dollars, and remind me of my worth and beauty.

I moved into this neighborhood just before starting eighth grade. Initially, making friends was challenging, but I eventually became close with someone living two houses down and another person on my street. Though they've since moved away, the memories remain vivid. Most of the original residents from when I first moved here still live in the area. My neighborhood is typical of American suburbia, featuring numerous two-story homes. During weekends and warm weather, you can hear children playing outside. The area remains peaceful most days, and I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors. People here respect your privacy but are ready to help when needed. I've never had packages stolen from my porch, which speaks to the trustworthiness of my neighbors.

There's a park just a couple minutes from my house that holds many memories. I've played various sports there with neighborhood friends - basketball, football, and baseball. While I did have one unfortunate incident where I got elbowed in the nose during football, the positive memories far outweigh the negative ones. These days, I mainly visit the park with my cousin's children, who get excited about the playground equipment. The park now fills me with nostalgia for many different reasons.

The neighborhood boasts impressive diversity, especially in terms of cuisine. Within a mile radius, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, though many people now prefer using delivery services like GrubHub and DoorDash. Fast food establishments are abundant, as they are in most suburban areas, and there are numerous pizza options as well.

The area is well-equipped with essential services - multiple dry cleaners, both Walgreens and CVS pharmacies, and a Midwest-favorite Jewel-Osco grocery store. There's even an Indian grocery store for those interested in authentic Indian ingredients or prepared foods. Overall, I'm quite satisfied with my neighborhood, and when I read about others' negative experiences with their neighbors on social media or in the news, I feel particularly grateful for my community.

I live in a neighborhood close to my college, which is one of the reasons I enjoy living there. The area is dominated by apartment buildings, with several reasonably priced restaurants and bars scattered throughout. One bar recently underwent a name change - it's a bit pricier, but the service and drinks are still decent. The community is diverse, consisting mainly of college students and working-class residents, owing to the affordable housing options. There's a lively presence of children due to an elementary school within walking distance.

While I don't know my neighbors personally (and prefer it that way), there's an amusing situation where management installed an air freshener outside one apartment due to frequent cannabis use - something my boyfriend and I find rather humorous. The surrounding buildings are generally older, though some have updated interiors. Further down the street, there are new apartment complexes, but I'm skeptical of their construction quality - they charge premium rates despite cheap construction, taking advantage of their proximity to campus.

There's an incredibly budget-friendly restaurant nearby that serves microwave-heated food on paper plates, and a gas station with a reportedly poor work environment. The area recently benefited from city funding that improved the road infrastructure, adding wide sidewalks and landscaping. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, though some have been removed, leaving stumps. The tree coverage is notably denser here compared to other parts of the neighborhood.

The contrast between streets is striking - while I live on 42nd Street, the parallel 43rd Street behind us is noticeably more run-down, with deteriorating sidewalks and shabby buildings partially concealed by trees. While there's some crime in the area, particularly in certain complexes, I generally feel content with my living situation. The affordable rent, proximity to the university, and convenient access to public transportation (with two nearby bus stops connecting to shopping areas and downtown) make it a practical choice for my needs.

I live in a unique neighborhood of duplexes arranged along a cul-de-sac. The buildings are strategically placed to give the appearance of single-family homes, all featuring yellow exteriors with white porches and green metal roofs. The community is remarkably close-knit, with most residents maintaining friendly relationships. We often gather spontaneously at the end of driveways in the evening, chatting while neighborhood children play with toys, draw with chalk, or fly kites. It's a refreshing contrast to today's technology-driven world, almost like stepping into the past.

Our community is nestled among fields and trees, beneath blue skies and drifting white clouds. The only drawback is the tornado season. Just last night, we experienced our first real tornado warning with actual sirens. I found myself in the bathtub clutching my small dog, purse, and pillows, while my larger dog refused to leave the living room, anxiously barking at the unusual situation. The neighborhood fell silent except for the sound of heavy hail. After the storm, the roads literally steamed as the temperature dropped dramatically from 92 to 75 degrees in minutes. The hail melted instantly on contact with the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, a magical moment occurred - the sun emerged while it was still raining, creating a double rainbow. I rushed to capture photos for my Facebook friends and family, who were as amazed as I was.

The streets remained quiet for an hour until residents returned from their storm shelters, after which normal life resumed - mothers and children outdoors while dinner prepared. As someone who recently relocated from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I find this friendly neighborhood charming, particularly the Southern accents. While all units are two-bedroom, two-bath duplexes that look identical outside, the interior layouts vary surprisingly, with some being quite compact.

I enjoy walking along the large field behind my home to the decorative pond, where I've spotted deer and hear bullfrogs singing in the morning. Located just forty minutes from Charlotte, this area offers a perfect blend of rural charm and urban accessibility. Each day begins with roosters crowing from nearby farms, creating a village-like atmosphere. There's even a donkey at a local farm whose evening braying has become part of our community's soundtrack. I consider myself fortunate to have discovered this wonderful neighborhood.

Having lived here for about a decade, I feel qualified to share my experience. When I first moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I was quite emotional and tearful because I deeply missed my old community. However, my parents made this decision for better opportunities - improved housing, a better high school, and generally a more upscale neighborhood for me and my younger sister.

Over time, I adapted and formed new relationships, both friendships and rivalries at school. While I didn't get to know many neighbors, Mr. Glen, his family, and Dennis, who lived next door, became almost like family to us. I have fond memories of attending Mr. Glen's second wedding with my family. It was a joyous celebration where I even caught the garter, though the bridal bouquet eluded me! I particularly enjoyed dancing with Marsharii, one of his daughters, though we've lost touch since then. I hope she's doing well in life.

The neighborhood itself is quite intricate, though GPS now helps me explore more confidently. I've had great times here with friends like Kason and Curtis, spending hours playing video games and living life to the fullest. I find peace in visiting the local park, where I practice balance with sticks from Home Depot and sometimes bring my wooden bokken sword. The park also has tennis and basketball courts - while I haven't played either sport recently, it's nice knowing they're available. My father and Mr. Graves taught me and my best friend tennis, pushing us hard but always keeping it enjoyable.

Looking back, this neighborhood has given me countless memorable experiences, and I'm optimistic that even better things lie ahead!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. While it may not stand out among other South Carolina towns, it plays a crucial role in the agricultural industry. Johnston proudly claims its title as the Peach Capital of the World, displaying this distinction on its welcome sign. The landscape is dominated by peach orchards and cattle farms. Outside the town center, homes are generously spaced apart, typically two-story structures featuring either metal roofs to cope with the intense summer heat or traditional gray shingles. Most houses are set back from the road, leaving space for agricultural activities in their front fields.

The town center is marked by a single traffic light at a four-way intersection, where all local businesses are concentrated. Dining options include three establishments: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a small burger chain. A former pizzeria recently closed its doors. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small family pharmacy, has gained local fame for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The town's sole grocery store, IGA (Independent Grocers Alliance), though somewhat expensive, serves mainly for quick purchases, as most residents prefer traveling to Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville for their major shopping needs.

Dollar General stands as the town's most popular retailer, offering a wide selection of everyday items and maintaining steady customer traffic throughout its business hours. Possibilities Furniture & More, a long-standing establishment run by a well-respected community member, offers furniture delivery service through two dedicated movers. The same building houses Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet care facility offering grooming, boarding, daycare, and other animal care services.

Both medical and veterinary services are available in quieter areas outside the town center, with small but well-equipped practices serving Johnston's residents. The town has one elementary school, after which students continue their education in a neighboring town. While Johnston currently lacks traditional recreational facilities, there are plans to develop a 2.5-acre recreational area to enhance family activities and attract newcomers.

Though the town may seem limited in entertainment options, lacking typical amenities like movie theaters, bowling alleys, social gathering spots, playgrounds, or diverse dining choices, it maintains its charm as a quintessential small town - one you might miss in the blink of an eye while passing through!

I reside in a typical suburban neighborhood in a small Tennessee town down south. Our street connects two state highways, which brings more traffic than I'd prefer, but otherwise, it's a peaceful area. The neighborhood has low turnover, so I'm familiar with most residents. People generally keep busy with lawn maintenance and daily routines. During winter, we enjoy sledding down the hill on our side street. Our house sits at the street's front corner, giving us a clear view of all the comings and goings, and we're familiar with local vehicles. Any unfamiliar car catches our attention. Many neighbors exercise by walking or take their dogs out. Children ride their bikes and play, just as you'd expect.

We spend considerable time at home since we work remotely. Our family consists of four people: my wife, myself, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. The neighbors are equally familiar with our routines. We enjoy outdoor activities, even in rainy weather. Occasionally, we barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with delightful cooking aromas. Someone's always mowing their lawn here - you can hear mowers almost daily from March through October, when grass growth finally slows.

Our neighborhood, originally woodland, has abundant trees providing plenty of shade, though this means substantial leaf cleanup in autumn. The annual ritual of raking and burning leaves is part of life here. I actually enjoy the scent of burning leaves - it's a pleasant herald of fall. Recently, our winters have been mild, making it feel like an extended autumn.

Our garage is located at the rear of our house, so we rarely use the front door except for occasional visitors. When I'm working on my truck or other projects with the garage doors open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are particularly peaceful, though Thanksgiving brings visiting family members and extra parked cars throughout the area. Similar scenarios occur during Christmas and Mother's Day.

Overall, I'm content living here. The only thing that would make it perfect would be if it weren't a through street.

I live in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by endless expanses of dirt. Unless you've lived here yourself, it's hard to truly grasp what it's like to be constantly surrounded by brown landscape, and when you do spot a green lawn, you know the owner is investing heavily in its maintenance. When I first moved here in the 1990s, houses were quite scattered. While that's still somewhat true today, there have been many new developments. The area is increasingly becoming urbanized, though this seems to be a common trend everywhere.

The community is generally friendly, but like any city, it has its better and worse areas. My immediate neighborhood is filled with friendly elderly residents, suggesting it's one of the nicer areas. The local businesses are mainly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For upscale shopping, you need to travel elsewhere, as we don't have establishments like Whole Foods.

Construction appears to be the dominant industry here, though I'm not citing official statistics. This makes sense given how underdeveloped the area still is, with plenty of open space for building. This concerns me somewhat, as I appreciate things as they are. I left a big city deliberately and don't wish to return to that environment. Speaking of construction, that's my field - I work as a drywall and T-bar installer.

What I particularly enjoy about living here is the wildlife. People are drawn to the high desert for various reasons, including its distinctive beauty. The unique climate and landscape have created special ecosystems that need protection and host diverse wildlife. It's important for residents to understand these non-human neighbors to ensure peaceful coexistence.

My family has adapted well to desert life. My three children are fascinated by lizards and desert insects - as I write this, they're outside trying to catch various creatures. We have several local attractions, including the San Bernardino County Fair in Victorville, which offers a genuine desert experience. Nearby Wrightwood offers snow-covered mountains and winter sports opportunities. The Victor Valley Museum is also worth visiting, featuring geological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical items that showcase the area's development and cultural heritage.

When describing my neighborhood, I believe my perspective offers something rather distinctive. Unlike most people who might speak about traditional residential areas, my situation is quite different. My neighborhood is actually my college campus, with my primary community being those who share my dormitory. I also consider the broader campus area as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser degree.

Despite this unconventional setting, my neighborhood shares many characteristics with traditional ones. Like any typical neighborhood, mine features housing, residents, commercial establishments, and recreational spaces. Let's first examine the "housing" in my area. There are three main types of residential facilities: apartment complexes, standalone houses, and dormitories.

The apartment buildings typically accommodate 2-4 residents per unit, with 4-6 units per floor. Most buildings are two stories tall, housing approximately 20 residents each. Then there are the traditional houses, available for rent to those affiliated with the institution. These houses, usually featuring 2-4 bedrooms, are often occupied by alumni, though they're less common due to space inefficiency. The dormitories, which are the most prevalent housing type, accommodate hundreds of students, typically with two students sharing each room.

Our community takes pride in its diversity, featuring residents from various cultural backgrounds and age groups. Faculty and staff typically occupy the standalone houses, while newer students reside in dormitories and upperclassmen tend to live in apartments.

As a self-contained community, our campus neighborhood offers numerous amenities. There are various dining establishments, campus-branded clothing stores, and grocery outlets, ensuring residents can find everything they need within the neighborhood boundaries. Our community park serves as a gathering space for all residents, maintained through collective effort to ensure it remains clean and safe for everyone's enjoyment.

In my neighborhood, sidewalks are scarce. The terrain slopes dramatically, and my house is perched at the summit of the steepest incline in the area - a hill that's earned the nickname "workout hill" from the many joggers who challenge themselves on it daily. With no sidewalks on our street, pedestrians share the road with vehicles. The pavement is damaged in spots, making driving somewhat treacherous. The utility lines crisscrossing our block appear worn and patched, largely due to frequent storms that send branches crashing into them, necessitating endless repairs.

Towering evergreens dominate the landscape, though they're not particularly beloved by residents who often remove them to preserve their ocean views. The houses here are strategically built on the hillside, featuring prominent second-story windows that cascade down the slope, each designed to capture the magnificent bay vista. The view is particularly stunning at sunset when the water seems to glow and the sky blazes orange, though more often than not, clouds filter the sunlight through a misty veil.

The perpetually damp climate encourages moss growth on virtually every surface - roofs, vehicles, and railings aren't spared. I learned this firsthand when my car developed a thick moss coating after just a month of sitting idle.

Despite a nearby school, the neighborhood demographic skews older, with retirees making up much of the population. Dogs, rather than children, are the prevalent presence, often seen lounging in yards or racing along streets. They're known to wander into open houses - I've had to escort one out of my living room before. Wild rabbits are abundant, much to gardeners' dismay but to my cats' delight, who've effectively reduced the local population. The area's bird life includes sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional raptors, though local crows quickly drive away any hawks or eagles.

While there aren't any stores nearby, the waterfront below offers several seafood restaurants. The shore itself is rocky rather than sandy, perfect for stone-throwing. The bay is intimate enough that the opposite shore remains visible even through the typical misty conditions.

Planning a visit to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn? You'll find it easily accessible, especially through New York City's extensive public transit system. This urban neighborhood maintains the authentic NYC feel while showcasing a unique cultural blend. Over the last twenty years, Bensonhurst has experienced a significant Asian population growth, evidenced by the numerous Asian-owned businesses lining its streets. You'll find Asian establishments - particularly supermarkets and laundromats - on practically every block. These businesses have become neighborhood staples, appreciated by locals for their excellent food quality, competitive prices, and convenience. To illustrate this, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking radius in my area alone.

However, Bensonhurst isn't exclusively Asian - it's a melting pot of cultures, home to immigrants and their first and second-generation American children. While many prominent local businesses are Asian-owned, the neighborhood offers other attractions, including a newly renovated park. This recreational space features ten basketball courts, a multipurpose field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, playground equipment, and a summer splash pad for children. True to New York City's spirit, the park reflects the area's diversity, with people from all backgrounds harmoniously sharing the space.

The neighborhood's architecture is predominantly residential, featuring co-op buildings, condominiums, and mostly two-family houses rather than corporate structures. While the community is generally friendly, noise can be an issue - expect to hear loud music from passing cars and revving engines, even in the early morning hours.

Visitors should exercise standard urban precautions, especially at night. While Bensonhurst is relatively safe, like any urban area, it has its share of troublemakers, bullies, and petty criminals. Package theft is a recurring issue, and despite city regulations requiring pet owners to clean up after their dogs, compliance is unfortunately low. Watch your step, as dog waste on sidewalks is a common nuisance throughout the neighborhood.

To understand Portland, Oregon, you must first grasp what "weird" truly means here. The city's unofficial motto, displayed on a building that houses an eclectic mix of businesses - a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club (operating in somewhat legally ambiguous ways) - proudly declares "Keep Portland Weird." For some, this represents nostalgia for the Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, when the city was less renowned and more affordable, fostering unique creative communities. For others, it's an invitation to a place where being called "weird" is actually a compliment.

Despite the recent influx of wealthy Californians and the endless construction of luxury condos to accommodate them, Portland maintains its distinctive character. Being weird here doesn't mean universal acceptance, but rather acceptance of what's typically rejected elsewhere. We still face modern challenges and enjoy modern conveniences - like everyone else in America, we rely heavily on imported goods. While there are countless ways to be unconventional, Portland also embraces the conventional. We have our share of yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and corporate professionals. Perhaps our "weirdness" lies in taking everything less seriously.

In my neighborhood, as in many Portland areas, you'll find vibrantly painted houses, street-side gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and during summer, the beloved "free boxes." These boxes (or bags) contain discarded items that often seem to magically find their perfect new owners. While typically filled with clothes and books, they might contain anything. This possibility of discovering treasure while walking through Southeast Portland captures the essence of the city - at least from my perspective, though I'm just one variety of weird among thousands.

Not everyone here would consider salvaging clothes from sidewalk boxes. Some prefer goat yoga (yes, that's exactly what it sounds like) or cheering for the Timbers soccer team. Portland is home to people passionate about diverse interests, dreamers who either pursue their aspirations or contemplate them over drinks at local bars.

The city faces its challenges too - drug problems, often rooted in mental health issues exacerbated by our notoriously rainy, grey weather. Our homeless crisis persists, drawing people with our relatively better social services, though still insufficient like elsewhere in America. The broader community's response oscillates between compassion and contempt - in this regard, we're not so weird after all.

The mountains stand eternal in the north, silent witnesses to each sunrise and sunset. Even when I'm too consumed by daily life to notice them, they remain steadfast and unmoved by the world's chaos. On my most troubled days, they command my attention, and when I turn to face them, they offer my restless spirit solace and the strength to persevere.

I first arrived here as an undergraduate student, and the northern mountains immediately captured my heart. While the university campus boasts its own beautiful features - stunning architecture, tranquil ponds, and majestic trees - it's the mountains that reign supreme in my affections.

The town itself is a tapestry of charm. Countless cafés have sheltered students during their caffeine-fueled study sessions. A short walk or bus ride to downtown reveals historic buildings with their weathered brick facades, where this seemingly quiet town suddenly pulses with urban energy. Yet this bustling atmosphere quickly gives way to tranquility beyond the library, creating a fascinating contrast that makes the city feel magical and worth exploring.

This place holds both precious and difficult memories. From late-night walks past rusty park swings with friends to rushed downtown trips catching movies at the elegant theater with university-provided tickets. The ponds, particularly, have witnessed both peaceful contemplation and tearful early-morning existential crises - the latter being more familiar to me. Watching the local wildlife - turtles, ducks, and insects - going about their purposeful lives often led me to question my own place in the world.

During one such moment, I found myself walking north past the pond, through suburban neighborhoods, until I reached a main street. As the sun cast its golden light across palm trees and painted the sky, I looked up to see those eternal mountains touching the hazy blue and yellow horizon. Without words, they spoke to me of endurance and resilience, reminding me of my own strength to carry on.

At first glance, you might overlook it - it's tucked away behind a shopping center in what appears to be just another residential zone, hardly the kind of place where you'd expect to find a thriving community. Yet, venture behind the vacant former Whole Foods and past the seasonally occupied hotels (save for the occasional summer family gatherings), and you'll discover a vibrant neighborhood hidden from view. Here, you'll find several apartment complexes arranged like carefully separated Russian nesting dolls, lined up methodically along the street. While the first complex you encounter has a somewhat controversial reputation in local news, let's focus instead on the neighboring buildings, which house a remarkably different world unknown to most locals.

Across the street stands a community college extension campus, its quiet buildings keeping watch over the road as sleepy students drift in with their morning coffee at 7 AM. The iron gates groan open to welcome them while frustrated commuters gesture impatiently on busier days. The street intersects with another residential road, flanked by a public park on one side and a rehabilitation center on the other, where patients recover from various injuries. The center features welcoming porch furniture and a leisurely spinning ceiling fan that stirs the heavy summer air.

At the park, children tumble through the grass while bees drift between roadside flowers. Retirees walking their dogs share the paths with skateboarding teenagers, offering disapproving glances to the boarders while politely acknowledging the groups of teenage girls huddled near the playground, chattering about boys and trending social media stars.

The adjacent strip mall hosts an affordable sushi restaurant that's mysteriously never crowded, a pool supply store, and a nail salon - a convenient trifecta where one could theoretically maintain their pool, get their nails done, and enjoy hibachi chicken simultaneously. A self-serve frozen yogurt shop draws park-going teens, who clutch their topping-laden treats while attempting skateboard tricks and vaping, convinced of their own coolness.

This neighborhood represents a slice of modern Americana - a corner of the unhurried South where time seems to stand still, preserving a uniquely American way of life.

My neighborhood has a unique character. While most houses are single-family dwellings, some have been converted into duplexes while maintaining their connected structure. My house features a modest front yard and a small driveway on the left side. Like most homes here, it evokes memories of a not-so-distant past when suburban living embodied the American dream. Though this dream once united Americans, it's now slowly fading. Yet our neighborhood, along with many others, stands as a testament that this dream hasn't completely disappeared.

The residents may not share the same optimism of yesteryear, and the yard maintenance isn't quite what it used to be, but every driveway still holds a car or two. Children still play as if their immediate surroundings are their entire universe. The nearly century-old public school continues to inspire future generations while stirring memories in older residents. While churches are sparse and mostly empty, the basketball courts remain vibrant with activity. Each house looks different but shares a common spirit.

There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a Yemeni family - perhaps the only Arab family in this predominantly African American neighborhood. The wide streets serve as impromptu football fields for local kids, who pause only to let cars pass. Many residents have deep roots here, spanning generations, and they often reminisce about times when everyone knew their neighbors.

A former karate school, which closed when martial arts movies fell out of fashion, has been replaced by a pharmacy. There's also a charming old movie theater offering discounted shows of classic films - avoided by younger viewers seeking new releases but cherished by older residents seeking an affordable night out.

A single expressway runs through our town, though its access points lie in the neighboring community. A previous proposal for a local exit was defeated when elders convinced the city council it would harm the town's character, despite youth support. As we construct a new high school, the community debates its mascot - though I personally think a cyborg cowboy with a log cabin would perfectly capture our town's essence.

Living in a major metropolitan area, I find myself in an incredibly diverse neighborhood. The layout intermingles residential and commercial zones, with businesses ranging from corporate offices to retail shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There's an endless selection of dining and shopping options. While major chain stores and corporate establishments are prevalent, boutique businesses are gaining popularity, appearing both in shopping centers and along streets that border otherwise peaceful residential areas.

The neighborhood features several parks that are popular among families with young children. The demographic makeup is notably diverse, with distinct communities coexisting in close proximity - including a thriving LGBTQ+ population, an Orthodox Jewish community, and immigrants from former Soviet states. The broader city hosts various ethnic enclaves like Koreatown, Chinatown, and Little Armenia, though they're separated by what can be surprisingly long drives despite relatively short distances.

Transportation is predominantly car-based, as walking isn't practical for most destinations despite some amenities being nearby. This reliance on vehicles results in notorious traffic congestion and parking challenges. Recent years have seen extensive development, particularly in high-rise residential buildings, though this growth has met resistance from current residents concerned about increasing population density and traffic.

The housing landscape is varied, featuring everything from single-family homes to duplexes, small apartment complexes, and condominiums. The population spans all age groups, though community bonds aren't as strong as they once were. I personally recall childhood memories of playing with neighborhood friends, a stark contrast to today's more disconnected atmosphere where many neighbors remain strangers to one another.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we passed endless cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, knowing she'd be shocked by the vast emptiness of the landscape. Coming from a place where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from home, she had never witnessed such expansive open space. Struck by the endless corn fields, I shared stories of my rural Ohio upbringing, and in that moment, she truly understood my roots.

Following a two-lane country road, you'll find a water-filled quarry, beyond which lies my small residential development. The houses, primarily built of brick and stucco, each sit on at least half an acre of meticulously maintained land. Spring brings an abundance of annual flowers alongside seasonal Midwestern trees. The driveways showcase gleaming high-end Mercedes Benz vehicles, freshly washed and sparkling in the midday sun.

As you approach my grey stucco house, you'll often see my Korean neighbor, always wearing a friendly smile. He spends his days mowing his lawn, singing over the mower's drone. Though age has dulled some of his sharp wit, this former doctor remains a beloved neighborhood character, often blending into the landscape with his John Deere Zero Turn mower.

At my home, geese roam the side yard, pursued by our playful Terrier. A small stream in the backyard flows to the quarry, accompanied by the sounds of bullfrogs and distant mooing from nearby farms. Across a handcrafted wooden bridge lies an untouched paradise of natural trees, herbs, and wildflowers - my childhood playground. Whether building tree forts or chasing wildlife, adventure always awaited, often shared with neighborhood friends.

Though winters here can be harsh, they transform the landscape into something magical. The lush green yard becomes a stark wilderness, with once-colorful trees standing bare against the sky. Snowfall creates an overnight wonderland, where my sister and I would leave our mark with snow angels and snowmen. Our childhood rivalries often played out in epic snowball fights, complete with elaborate fort constructions serving as our arsenals. In this personal wonderland, we lived out our carefree childhood days, lost in imagination and play.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here.
